item.title: being honest with yourself
item.description: there comes a time when you start realizing just how many lies you tell yourself. stuff like assumptions about way things work, ways you think people interpret what you do, ways you think things should go, and ways you do the things you do. one i’m recently trying to tackle is my perception of the difficulty of “doing” things. people say stuff like, going to the gym is “hard”. but what if it weren’t hard?

item.title: my current favorite hoodie
item.description: i’m a big hoodie enjoyer. i have a huge collection in my closet, and it is my preferred top layer. the usual issues i have with finding “good hoodies” are that they need to meet certain criteria, namely: a boxy silhouette (my chest is wide) slightly cropped, but not too cropped (my torso is short) arms that are nice and baggy but NOT too long (something that has a cuff that sits halfway on your hand is super ideal for the cozy vibe) a nice, structured hood that is big enough for my big ass head a heavy enough weight to conquer any morning when i feel like absolute garbage about the way i look a big enough kangaroo pouch/pockets to rest my hands in comfortably for a while, i was rocking Abercrombie’s relaxed popover hoodies.

item.title: fruitmaxxing
item.description: i’ve been on a fruit kick lately. apples, bananas, even some pears. throw a few oranges in there too. this stuff is honestly the shit. sugar, carbs, fiber, all in a nice little package that doesn’t feel like absolute dogshit for your body to be consuming? sign me up. i’m not sure when i fell off the fruit bandwagon, but boy was i an idiot for letting that happen. it’s literally as the saying goes.

item.title: thoughts of the new year
item.description: what do you think about when you think of the new year? my mind goes to the winter season in animal crossing games. animal crossing is, as you know, one of my favorites. christmas, of course, is represented by the complete darkness of the living room save for the beacon of light that is the christmas tree left on overnight to keep the magic of the holiday alive.
